metadata.title: The Ultimate Guide to Getting Started in Data Science | by Anne Bonner | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The Ultimate Guide to Getting Started in Data Science
metadata.description: It’s not easy to break into a new field, especially one as complex and multi-faceted as data science. We’re living in a weird time where even the definition (and expectations) of data science changes…

all_paragraphs: I want to tell you something:

It’s not easy to break into a new field, especially one as complex and multi-faceted as data science. We’re living in a weird time where even the definition (and expectations) of data science changes from company to company. What a data scientist used to do, used to need to understand, and the types of companies that need to hire data scientists are in a state of rapid evolution.
Why in the world would there be only one path to follow?
Honestly, if you’re trying to break into data science, I can’t think of a better time to get started!
If you can take on a graduate degree, go for it! All things being equal, higher education is the most reliable way to start working in data science.

But it isn’t the only way, it probably isn’t the best way, and that way definitely doesn’t work for everyone. Since I went from zero skills to getting job offers and consulting requests in under six months, I thought I’d share my unconventional journey along with some of the best information from incredible stories we’ve published here on Towards Data Science.
Get out of your own way and get involved!
This is for everyone who needs to take the road less travelled.
This article is part of the Ask Me Anything series at Towards Data Science. We’ve gotten some great questions since we started, and this one really stood out.

As someone lucky enough to have read a lot of wonderful success stories (and some really fabulous not-quite-success stories), I can tell you with absolute certainty that there is no single way to get started in data science.
I can also tell you that there is a nearly endless number of people who want to help you along the way. Take advantage of that!
With or without a degree, the first thing you should do is look at the specific area of data science that interests you.
It’s not as straightforward as you might think.

The term “data science” as it relates to job opportunities covers a pretty fluid and extensive area of expertise and possible career options right now! (It’s a safe bet that finding a job in a new field is the reason you’re reading this article. If you’re stopping by to parse out the traditional definitions of “data science” and “data scientist” hop on down to the comment section.)
For example, you might be interested in a specific job or field that focuses on:

or a whole lot of other specialities. We’re in a weird time where more companies know they need to hire data scientists than know what, exactly, data scientists do. Take advantage of that and find your niche! (Here’s a fantastic article about the mismatch between what hiring managers and executives want delivered and who they’re hiring to do the job.)

Now identify specific companies that do the work you want to do. Make sure you find companies where you’d be excited to work! Research previous job postings that they’ve created and tailor your learning path to fit those requirements. You’ll likely see that you’ll need to learn Python or R, SQL, possibly AWS, Spark, Hadoop, and so on. You’ll want to learn about data visualization techniques and tools. Depending on what interests you, you may need to learn concepts like natural language processing, image recognition, machine learning techniques, and so on. You might also find that the job you want requires that candidates have a Masters or a PhD in a specific area of study. That’s essential information! If the company you want to work for uses an algorithm to screen candidates and your resume doesn’t match their specifications, no human will ever set eyes on it.

If you want to work for one specific company, learn what they require from successful candidates, make a list, and start checking off everything you learn as you go. And never, ever forget the power of domain knowledge! It won’t be in the job post, but learn about the specific issues and challenges that the industry you’re looking at faces. Pay attention to soft skills too! They can seriously set you apart from the competition. If you already have experience communicating, presenting, managing, speaking, and so on, you’re ahead of the game.

If you’re feeling brave, reach out to someone at the organization where you want to work with an email that says that you’re entering the field and you want to work there more than anywhere else. Ask them what would make you the ideal candidate for a future position! Maybe they won’t respond, but I’ll bet some of them do.
If you get a response, no matter what that response is, send them a note saying how grateful you are that they took the time to respond.

If you can get a graduate degree, do it! There’s no substitute for high-quality education and the networking possibilities that it offers. We’ve published incredible articles here from people who have used their education to the fullest and have gotten out there and started conquering the fields of data science, machine learning, artificial intelligence, and more.

But maybe higher education isn’t going to work for you right now. That’s okay! A PhD is a great thing to have and it can, without question, open doors for you. But having a degree is not a guarantee that you’ll get a job or that you’ll be great at your job. Having an advanced degree does not, in any way, guarantee that you’ll be a successful candidate for a particular job. Here’s a really good perspective of what makes a great data scientist.

There’s also nothing that says that you need a specific level of education to become a data scientist. Would it help to have it? Of course! But more and more, people are finding that having completed great online courses plus having a fantastic portfolio of projects that you’ve thought through and developed on your own combined with additional experience (previous work experience and open source contributions, for example) can be as effective (if not more) than simply having a certain degree.

You can find countless excellent articles from writers who have taken a slightly less traditional path and from writers who argue that having an advanced degree isn’t preparation enough for the real world. We’ve also published articles from authors who have taken an in-depth look at the skills required to become a data scientist (the author wrote this one for 2018 and has an update for 2019) and specifically at whether or not you need a graduate degree to work in data science.

For a long time, data scientists truly were scientists. Education was crucial! Now, however, with the rampant and overwhelming increase in available data and the necessity for businesses to process that data in meaningful ways (as well as the availability of technology, tools, and libraries that didn’t exist ten years ago), the field of data science has changed.

Today, there are a ton of business who have read that they need to have data scientists but don’t have a specific plan or specific expectations for a data science team. A number of businesses who are looking for data scientists are really in need of a data analyst or a business analyst. Some companies just need help making sense of the piles of data that they’re sitting on and might ask you to create basic predictive models. Some businesses are really looking for data engineers or machine learning engineers. Because the field is in a time of evolution and fluidity, an advanced degree is no longer an absolute requirement. Having the ability to deal with a company’s data, analyze it, and communicate your findings in a meaningful way does not necessarily require a PhD anymore.
But if you want to get a real head start on the process and you can make it happen, get that education! It can only help you.

If, for whatever reason, the Masters/PhD thing doesn’t work for you, take a look at the huge number of online courses out there! They aren’t all good, of course. You’ll want to look at which courses teach what you want to know, which courses are popular and have great reviews, which courses successful people in the field have taken, and so on.
If you can focus on this path and dedicate yourself to it, there’s no reason you can’t be in a fantastic position to get hired in data science before the end of this year.

First and foremost, think about your learning style! Some people learn best by reading, some by listening, some by watching videos, some by working through exercises. Some people need to find answers on their own, and some need to have the answers provided so they can see them and work backwards. Whatever your style, there’s a fleet of courses out there for you! (No matter what you choose, though, make sure you type through every single line of code yourself. There’s no substitute. Making your fingers do the work gets that information in your head in a shockingly effective way!)

I’d highly recommend getting started for free, just to make sure that you enjoy the work and not only the hype. You can find fabulous free resources across the web. Here is a great compilation of free resources!

If you don’t have any coding experience, you might want to take a look at some online courses that teach the programming language that interests you. Python and R are the most popular choices for data science. There are a number of reasons for picking one over the other, but Python has been leading the field for a number of years now and it remains the smart first choice (unless, of course, you already know that R is a requirement for the positions that interest you). Choose the language that’s right for you!
Obviously, that’s what worked for my learning style and I chose to learn Python. If you have courses you’ve liked, share them in the comments!
If you want to start learning to code, you could check out:

Make sure you’re reading at least one or two articles and/or listening to a data science podcast or watching data science videos every day. You can read articles in the bathroom or listen to podcasts in bed if you need to, but do it. Take advantage of the incredible wealth of knowledge that’s out there to stay current and get comfortable with the language of data science. Of course, I recommend the articles here on Towards Data Science, our podcast, and our YouTube channel, but you have a lot of options!
We recently published this great list of the top 20 data science podcasts.

Now buckle down and get on those math skills. You want to be comfortable with statistics, linear algebra, and basic calculus at the very least. Don’t be afraid of math! Math skills are critical if you’re going to work in this field. Brush up on your skills at Khan Academy or maybe take advantage of some free courses on Udacity.
This article does a great job of outlining necessary data science math skills and how to start learning data science for free!

Once you’ve started getting comfortable with your chosen programming language and you’re getting a little cosier with statistics (at the very least), start checking out data science courses! You don’t need to be an expert programmer to get started with introductory online courses. But a basic familiarity will help you avoid feeling overwhelmed. You might want to check out Coursera, Udacity, Udemy, and edX, or you might be interested in Datacamp, Dataquest, Springboard, or Elite Data Science. Also, Coursera allows you to audit courses for free! You won’t get an official certificate, but you will get the information without spending a dime. (You can also apply for financial aid with Coursera).
Are you someone who learns well by reading? Did you know that you can learn on Towards Data Science? We’ve curated some of our best articles by topic to help you learn more at your own pace!

Still interested in working in data science? Start looking for scholarships, challenges, and competitions! You wouldn’t believe the information available out there through scholarship programs and challenges. I’ve done the Bertelsmann Data Science Scholarship challenge through Udacity, the Facebook AI PyTorch scholarship challenge, and the Secure and Private AI scholarship challenge and there are a lot more out there. Each of these challenges teaches truly useful information and puts you in contact with an incredible community of people for free.

Make sure you connect with the amazing people in your courses and challenges on LinkedIn! While you’re at it, make sure your LinkedIn profile looks good. Fill out your education section, certificates, skills, and add any projects you’ve completed. Write a quality “about me” section that showcases who you are and how you can help other people. (You’d be surprised what a difference changing “I am experienced with data visualization techniques” to “I can help you use your data to tell great stories” can make!) Endorse the skills of some of the people that you’ve gotten to know well and they might just endorse some of your skills in return.

Once you start getting comfortable with these concepts, you’ll see that you need to start adding a few more tools to your toolbox. SQL is incredibly important. You definitely want to start getting comfortable with data visualization techniques too. There are, of course, tools that you’ll have been using in your online courses, and you might also want to get familiar with Tableau if you haven’t already. It’s a popular tool, and it does a great job of visually communicating data analysis in a way that’s effective for beginners on both sides of the table. You definitely want to be familiar with the workings of Git and GitHub, and there are a lot of online courses available. (This is a decent free course for beginners. This one deals specifically with version control and tends to be more highly recommended.)

Start looking at Kaggle! Not everyone uses Kaggle or participates in competitions, but they’re an incredibly helpful resource for people who are interested in putting their skills to the test. Also, doing well on Kaggle can propel you into some interesting situations and brand new careers. There are a lot of people who have worked hard putting together their best tips and tricks for Kaggle success, so don’t feel like you have to figure out everything on your own.
Are you interested in hackathons? We’ve heard some amazing stories from people who have gotten ready for and participated in hackathons and had some pretty astounding experiences.

Still going? It might be time to start looking at paid courses. I’m a fan of the Udacity Nanodegrees, but you may want to invest in Coursera or edX courses. You might even decide that a Bootcamp is right for you.
You might want to do Udacity’s Data Science Nanodegree or their Machine Learning Nanodegree. You might also be interested in programs like:
We’ve published great stories from people who have attended Bootcamps at:

Now it’s time to focus on your projects! Clean up your GitHub profile. Make sure you’re pushing commits every day if you can and feature the best of your projects. At this point, you will have put together some projects in your courses and should be comfortable enough to start working on a project of your own. Find a topic that genuinely interests you and build something amazing or look at something in a new way! Solve a problem! Really get in there and make this project your own. You never know where a personal project might take you.
Working on something you care about will give you something that you can talk about in a new way at a new level. This will help you when you’re networking and when you’re interviewing!

Now start contributing to open source organizations! Make some meaningful contributions to organizations on GitHub. GitHub has a section devoted to projects that are great for new contributors! You can search for projects that are tagged specifically for first-timers or are beginner-friendly. There’s also a solid GitHub repo dedicated to excellent first PR opportunities that’s worth checking out.

Find an organization that you can really help or one that seriously interests you and get involved. Most open source organizations are operating with little to no budget and appreciate all the help they can get. They want you to succeed! I’ve worked closely with the incredible people over at NumPy, and they honestly want to help people understand the process of contributing to NumPy so that they feel comfortable contributing long-term. They don’t want you to give up! It’s not a simple process, but they want you to succeed and keep contributing.

Help with known issues, help with documentation, help with whatever you can! If you find an organization that clicks with you and your interests, make helping them a priority. You may find yourself on their team before you know it!
(Head’s up! You’re now building experience that will make your resume stand out!)
Also, I’ve said it before, and I’ll say it again. Start writing!!!

Write about what you learn. Write to share your information and help other people. You’ll be astonished by the difference between understanding a concept and understanding a concept well enough to write about it. Also, the tech community is heavily invested in helping others (just look at everything from open source organizations to Quora, Stack Overflow, and so on) and you want to add your voice to the community.

On a personal note: writing is hands-down the best way I’ve found to get noticed as a beginner! The opportunities I’ve been offered as a result of my articles are mindblowing. I’ve been offered positions as a consultant, speaking engagements, writing and editing work, teaching and mentoring positions, data science positions, and more based solely on these articles.

So now you have great projects that you can talk about in-depth, a series of articles that demonstrate what you know and what you’ve learned, a solid GitHub profile, several certificates to your name, you’ve been contributing to open source organizations, and you may have even completed a Kaggle competition or two or participated in a hackathon. You have an optimized LinkedIn profile that showcases your experience, your skills, and your connections. You’ve also (I hope) been fleshing out your resume with projects, skills, and open source experience and it’s ready to go.

Get out there and start connecting with people! As much fun as it is to just blindly send out your resume to hundreds of organizations that are advertising jobs and using algorithms and recruiters to screen candidates, you might find that the quickest (and least painful) way to get hired is to have an actual conversation with someone at an organization!

Remember those emails you sent out at the beginning of the process? Reach out to those people again and thank them once more for their help. Remind them who you are and let them know what you’ve accomplished in such a short time. Mention how excited you would be to talk to someone in the company. Demonstrate your communication skills, your ability to follow advice, and how self-motivated you are. See what kind of response you get!

Talk to the people from your scholarships and courses who have found great jobs and see what they’ve learned. You might also want to have a conversation or two with the people you’ve connected with in that open source organization. You never know, they might even be able to recommend you for a cool position. That’s basically what LinkedIn is all about!

For those of you out there who are introverted, have low self-esteem, and are suffering from a massive case of imposter syndrome…never, ever, ever forget that there are many companies out there that offer a referral bonus to people who successfully recommend a candidate for a job opening. One or two of your connections might just be interested in earning a little money…

Also, remember that people don’t know the things that you haven’t told them. Do you know which of your LinkedIn connections are looking for work? Do you know how many of the other people at that open source organization are actively trying to find jobs? Probably not! We like to assume that people know everything about us, but they don’t. Speak up! You might be amazed at how many people out there would love to lend a hand if they can.
Stop procrastinating! Get out there and start working in data science!
Thanks for reading! As always, if you do anything cool with this information, let everyone know about it in the comments below or reach out any time!
Looking for more fun articles? You might be interested in these:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Building a community space at VentureBeat 💫 Submit your articles here: http://bit.ly/submissions2023
